title-group.article-title: Effects of water hardness and temperature on the acute toxicity of mercuric chloride on rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss)

contrib-group.aff: Rize University, Faculty of Fisheries, Rize, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Ertugrul Terzi, Rize University, Faculty of Fisheries, Rize, Turkey. Email: ertugrulterzi@gmail.com

abstract.p: In this study, the toxicity of mercuric chloride (HgCl2), an important pollutant threatening water resources for many years, and the effects of water temperature and hardness on the toxicity in cultured rainbow trout Oncorhynchus mykiss (4.79 ± 0.16 g; 7.38 ± 0.24 cm; mean ± SD) were investigated at different temperatures (12 and 17°C) and hardness concentrations (35, 70 and 120 mg l–1 as calcium carbonate, CaCO3). For this purpose, the acute toxicity tests were performed by 96-h static tests in different water temperatures and water hardness concentrations. For acute toxicity tests, solutions ranging from 0.4 to 1.2 mg l–1 were used at 12°C and solutions ranging from 0.4 to 1.0 mg l–1 at 17°C. The LC50 values of HgCl2 that killed 50% of rainbow trout within 96 h in the hardness concentrations of 35, 70 and 120 mg l–1 CaCO3 were calculated using probit analysis, and were found to be 0.725, 0.788, 0.855 mg l–1 at 12°C and 0.670, 0.741, 0.787 mg l–1 at 17°C, respectively. Consequently, the toxicity of HgCl2 on rainbow trout decreased when the temperature decreased from 17 to 12°C. Toxicity increased when the hardness decreased from 120 to 35 mg l–1 CaCO3. In contrast to temperature, water hardness presents a negative effect on the toxicity of HgCl2.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Contaminants of agricultural and industrial processes consist of highly toxic chemicals like heavy metals and pesticides that lead to pollution of aquatic environments. The accumulation and persistence of metals and pesticides in the aquatic environment constitute a threat to biological life, as witnessed by the chronic and acute poisoning of fish and other aquatic organisms (George, 1990; Langston, 1990).

Mercury is known as a widespread and persistent pollutant occurring in a variety of forms in freshwater and marine ecosystems (Satoh, 2000). Also, mercuric compounds are very toxic and the toxicity of mercury has been known since the beginning of the 16th century (Ramalingam et al., 2001). Mercuric chloride (HgCl2) has been used in agriculture as fungicide, in medicine as a topical antiseptic and disinfectant. HgCl2 is commonly used for industrial, scientific and agricultural purposes around the world as well as in Turkey (Verep et al., 2007).

Water quality used in the toxicity tests of aquatic organisms affects the lethal concentration of metals. Beşli (2006) reported that salinity affected the toxicity of HgCl2 on rainbow trout. Straus and Tucker (1993) reported that total alkalinity and total hardness had significant effects on acute copper toxicity in juvenile channel catfish (Ictalurus punctatus). Wurts and Perschbacher (1994) observed that alkalinity concentration had the most pronounced effect on acute copper toxicity in juvenile channel catfish, when calcium hardness and alkalinity concentrations were treated as independent variables. Perschbacher and Wurts (1999) also reported a calcium hardness effect, which could affect the tolerance of channel catfish to copper toxicity in low-alkalinity environments. Miller and Mackay (1980) believed calcium hardness was more important than alkalinity in protecting fish from copper toxicity, based on experiments with juvenile rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss). Research with fathead minnows (Pimephales promelas) and rainbow trout, however, found no significant calcium effect on copper uptake sites (Lauren and McDonald, 1987; Playle et al., 1993; Zia and McDonald, 1994).

The contamination of aquatic ecosystems by metals has gained increasing attention in recent decades. Although the toxicity of HgCl2 to aquatic organisms is obvious (Beşli, 2006; Gül et al., 2008; Pardey et al., 2005; Verep et al., 2007), no study has been conducted to determine the effects of water temperature and water hardness on the acute toxicity of HgCl2 on rainbow trout (Table 1 ).

sec.p: The present study was conducted to determine the effects of water temperature and hardness on the acute toxicity of the heavy metal compound HgCl2 in a static aquaria system of rainbow trout. This species was selected for bioassays because it can easily adapt to the laboratory conditions and it is available throughout the year.

sec.title: Experiment animals
sec.p: Juvenile rainbow trout (4.79 ± 0.16 g; 7.38 ± 0.24 cm; mean ± SD) were obtained from a local trout breeding farm and then transferred to the laboratory in Faculty of Fisheries, Rize University. Fish were held in two closed water recirculating systems (600 l) for at least 15 days to acclimate to the laboratory conditions prior to experiments. During the acclimation period, about 20% of the water in each recirculating system was replaced daily. Throughout the acclimation period and subsequent periods of HgCl2 exposure, fish were held under a photoperiod of 12-h light and dark cycle. During acclimation, fish were fed with commercial trout pellets twice a day at 5% of their body weight. Fish were fed until 2 days before exposure and not fed during the toxicity tests. No fish died during this period. During acclimation, the water in the aquarium had following characteristics: dissolved oxygen, 8.2 ± 0.20 mg l−1; temperature, 11.97 ± 0.4°C; pH 7.81 ± 0.15; total alkalinity, 26.6 ± 1.2 mg l–1 as calcium carbonate (CaCO3); unionized ammonia, 12.1 ± 2.1 ng l–1, and nitrite 8.4 ± 2.6 µg l–1.

sec.title: Water quality
sec.p: Physicochemical characteristics of the experimental water revealed that they were similar to the standard values under natural conditions as they did not contain any toxic substances. However, few changes were observed in the quality of water at two temperatures and were related to dissolved oxygen, ammonia and nitrite (Table 2 ). The characteristics of water quality in each treatment were measured daily during exposure to HgCl2. Total ammonia was measured by an indophenol method and nitrite was measured by an azo method (Boyd and Tucker, 1992). Total hardness and total alkalinity were measured by the titration method. Dissolved oxygen concentration was measured by the Winkler method. Water temperature and pH were determined with a glass electrode (Hach Lange HQ40D Düsseldorf, Germany).

sec.title: Acute toxicity experiments
sec.p: The experiment was conducted based on guidelines provided by Altinok (2004). Briefly, the fish were examined and determined to be free of external parasites before chemical exposure (AFS–FHS, 2003). After acclimation, fish from one of the acclimation tanks were randomly transferred to glass aquaria containing 25 l of static water (10 fish per aquarium). Quadruplicate aquaria were designated for each concentration and different HgCl2 concentrations were added to the test aquaria. No HgCl2 was added to the control aquaria. During the 96-h acute toxicity experiment, water in each aquarium was aerated and the water quality parameters were measured in the control time. Fish mortality was recorded as 0, 6, 12, 18, 24, 48, 72 and 96 h after exposure to HgCl2. When gill opercula and body movement ceased, fish were considered dead and removed immediately.

sec.title: Effects of temperature on toxicity
sec.p: Growth and yield of rainbow trout were maximum at 10–18°C (Hokanson et al., 1977). 11.96 ± 0.09 and 17.01 ± 0.13°C) were used to determine the toxic effect of HgCl2 on rainbow trout at different total hardness concentrations. Room temperatures were controlled and maintained using an air-conditioning unit. Aquaria were designated for each temperature and each aquarium contained 10 fish. HgCl2 concentrations of each aquarium were adjusted to 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, 1.0 and 1.2 mg l–1 at 12°C and 0.4, 0.5, 0.6, 0.7, 0.8 and 1.0 mg l–1 at 17°C. During the 96-h acute toxicity experiment, water was aerated and its characteristics were measured daily (Table 2).

sec.title: Effects of hardness on toxicity
sec.p: Three hardness concentrations were used according to the classification of Briggs and Ficke (1977). Soft (35 ± 0.5), moderately hard (70 ± 0.8) and hard water (120 ± 0.8 mg l–1 as CaCO3) were used to determine the toxic effect of HgCl2 on rainbow trout at different temperatures. Ten fish per aquarium were transferred after adjusting the total hardness of test water by adding CaSO4 and MgSO4 (1:1) based on the weight ratio. Total alkalinity was held constant at 26.5 ± 3.3 mg l–1 of CaCO3. During the 96-h acute toxicity experiment, water was aerated and its characteristics were measured daily (Table 2).

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: The nominal concentration of HgCl2 estimated to kill 50% (LC50) of rainbow trout within 24 h, 48 h, 72 h and 96 h was calculated by probit analysis, according to the maximum-likelihood procedure. Relations between percentage fish mortality and HgCl2 concentrations were analysed using correlation analysis. Also, data were analysed statistically by two-way analysis of variance (ANOVA), the dependent variable being the lethal concentration of HgCl2.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Toxicity tests for HgCl2 were conducted to find the changes in the LC50 values for different hardness and temperatures of test water. No fish died during the acclimation period before HgCl2 exposure, and no control fish died during the toxicity tests. When fish were exposed to 0.6 and 0.8 mg l–1 or higher concentrations of HgCl2 at 12 and 17°C, respectively, fish exhibited signs of restlessness, erratic swimming, flashing, convulsions, and loss of balance. Fish constantly tried to jump out of the tank and hit the aquarium wall. Fish also had excessive mucus. The mouth and opercula were open when the fish died. Mortality of fish increased significantly with increasing temperature from 12 to 17°C but decreased with increasing the total hardness from 35 to 120 mg l–1 of CaCO3. The concentrations of HgCl2 that killed 50% of the rainbow trout within 96 h at different total hardness and temperature are shown in Figure 1 . Also, there were significant relations between percentage fish mortality and HgCl2 concentrations from 0.4 to 1.2 mg l–1 (p < 0.001 and r = 0.984 at 12°C and 35 mg l–1 CaCO3; p < 0.001 and r = 0.990 at 12°C and 70 mg l–1 CaCO3; p < 0.001 and r = 0.984 at 12°C and 120 mg l–1 CaCO3; p < 0.001 and r = 0.970 at 17°C and 35 mg l–1 CaCO3; p < 0.001 and r = 0.965 at 17°C and 70 mg l–1 CaCO3 and p < 0.001 and r = 0.980 at 17°C and 120 mg l–1 CaCO3). The LC50 ranged from 0.670 to 0.855 mg l–1 and varied significantly among temperature (12 and 17°C) and hardness concentrations (35, 70 and 120 mg l–1 CaCO3), calculating the highest and lowest values in soft water at 17°C (0.670 mg l–1) and hard water at 12°C (0.855 mg l–1), respectively (Figure 1). The LC50 followed a decreasing trend when the hardness decreased. There was a statistically significant difference in the mean values among the different levels of hardness (F 3, 18 = 46.876, p < 0.001) and temperature (F 2, 18 = 29.695, p < 0.001). The effect of different levels of hardness did not depend on the temperature. There was no statistically significant interaction between hardness and temperature (p = 0.723).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The toxic effects of chemicals on aquatic species generally occur due to the interactions of various environmental parameters. Of these parameters, hardness and temperature are the primary factors affecting the metal toxicity. Most studies have used LC50 as a reference toxicity value calculated from standard test methods, without considering the hardness and temperature of test waters, when determining the toxicity of HgCl2. As shown in the present study, the observed toxic effects of HgCl2 on rainbow trout were different at the different tests of water hardness and temperature. The 96-h LC50 value of HgCl2 ranged from 0.670 to 0.855 mg l–1 because the total hardness and temperature changed. In aquatic toxicology, if LC50 concentration is smaller than 1 mg l–1, the chemical is highly toxic; and if the concentration is between 1 and 10 mg l–1, then it is considered to be moderately toxic (Louis et al., 1996), therefore it is reported here that HgCl2 is highly toxic to rainbow trout and may cause many damage in this fish. Mortality rate increased with increasing test temperatures and decreasing total hardness of water. The 96-h LC50s of HgCl2 with water hardness of 35, 70 and 120 mg l–1 at 12°C for rainbow trout were 0.725, 0.788 and 0.855 mg l–1; at 17°C were 0.670, 0.741 and 0.787 mg l–1, respectively. 96 h LC50 values of HgCl2 with all concentrations of water hardness in the present study were lower than the results for some researchers. For example, Gupta and Rajbanshi (1991) found that LC50 values of cadmium (Cd) ions in hard water for Heteropneustes fossilis and Channa punctatus were 14.60 – 20.60 mg l–1 and 6.81–7.40 mg l–1, respectively. Kumar and Kumar Gupta (2006) also reported LC50 values for catla, rohu and mrigal were 72.729, 278.347 and 312.909 μg Hg l–1, respectively. Furthermore, Pascoe et al. (1986) reported that the LC50 value of cadmium in hard water for rainbow trout was 26 mg 1–1. These 96-h LC50 value of HgCl2 for rainbow trout were considerably higher than those reported for Rasbora daniconius (LC50–0.08 mg Hg l–1) (Gupta and Rajbanshi, 1995), Notemigonus crysoleuces and Gambusia affinis (LC50–16.75 and 52.62 μg Hg l–1, respectively) (McCrary and Heagler, 1997). Verep et al. (2007) found that the 96-h LC50 for HgCl2 for rainbow trout was 0.814 mg l–1 at 15°C and at 61–65 mg l–1 CaCO3 total hardness. These results indicate greater toxicity of HgCl2 for rainbow trout juveniles with increasing temperatures from 12 to 17°C. The cause of the inverse relationship is speculated to be reduced functioning at lower temperatures of resisting mechanisms for HgCl2 toxicity. These could include decreased enzyme production, levels and rates of activity; decreased membrane transport and clearance rates from the body. The LC50 values for HgCl2 range from 0.217 to 0.814 mg l–1 in rainbow trout (Buhl and Hamilton, 1991; Verep et al., 2007). Moreover, toxicity of metals decreases in hard water because Ca2+ and Mg2+ ions reduce the permeability of the fish gills. So uptake of toxicants from the gills to the body is difficult.
As expected, when the total hardness concentration is higher and water temperature in the toxicity experiment for metal toxicity is lower, a higher concentration of HgCl2 is required for mortality.
